hero.subtitle: From California funk scenes to Bronx blocks, club floors to global stages — the diverse stories of movement, rhythm, and revolution that changed the world.

overview.description: From early funk styles to breakbeats, ballroom battles to global stages — explore the diverse dance styles that shaped culture and connected communities worldwide.

streetSection.subtitle: From the streets of the Bronx to global stages, discover the authentic origins of the movement that revolutionized dance, music, and culture forever.
streetSection.description: Born in the Bronx in the 1970s, street dance emerged from block parties, street corners, and the creative spirit of young people.

impact.title: THE IMPACT
impact.description: What started on the streets became a global phenomenon, influencing art, fashion, and society.

cards.title: THE MOVEMENT
cards.description: Breaking, popping, Campbellock (Locking) - these are the foundational styles that defined street dance.

hipHopFoundation.name: Hip-Hop Foundation
hipHopFoundation.description: The original elements born from 1970s Bronx block parties - breaking, DJing, MCing, and the street dance styles that started it all.

funkStyles.name: Funk Styles
funkStyles.description: West Coast funk-driven styles like popping and Campbellock (Locking), born from the soul and groove of 1970s California dance culture.

clubHouse.name: Club & House Culture
clubHouse.description: Underground club styles including house, footwork, hustle, and club dances that emerged from Chicago, NYC, and disco scenes from the 1970s-80s.

ballroomCulture.name: Ballroom Culture
ballroomCulture.description: The art of voguing, Wh/aacking, and punking from ballroom competitions, born from Harlem’s LGBTQ+ ballroom community in the 1970s-80s.

modernStreet.name: Modern Street
modernStreet.description: Contemporary street styles influenced by social media, global connectivity, and the new generation of urban dancers.

africanDiaspora.name: African Diaspora Roots
africanDiaspora.description: Traditional and contemporary styles rooted in African diaspora cultures across the Caribbean, Latin America, and beyond.

styles.title: EXPLORE
styles.subtitle: Discover the foundational dance styles that built the culture

content: Locking is a high-energy funk dance style known for its playful attitude, theatrical moves, and signature freezes called ’locks.’ Dancers use exaggerated gestures, sharp stops, and expressive character to connect with the audience and the music.

The style celebrates individuality, musicality, and crowd interaction. Locking’s vibrant personality and improvisational spirit make it a favorite in battles, performances, and street dance culture worldwide.

summary: Locking began in Los Angeles in 1970 when Don Campbell created the Campbellock by accident—turning a failed attempt at another dance into a new style. His unique freezes and playful energy quickly caught on, and the dance became a sensation in clubs and on TV.
Don Campbell’s innovation inspired The Lockers crew and helped bring funk styles to the mainstream, making Locking a cornerstone of street dance history.
content: Donald Odell Campbell was born January 8th, 1951. In 1970, at just 19 years old, Don Campbell created the dance ’The Campbellock’ at LA Trade Technical College in Downtown LA.

Don was first and foremost an artist — a portrait artist who understood how art could garner expression and move people. When he tried to do a dance called ’The Robot Shuffle’ but couldn’t execute it properly, his unique ’mistakes’ became the foundation of something revolutionary.
Like ’The Lock’ itself, all of Don’s moves were never premeditated. They were the result of improvisation and interaction with others, dictated by the feel of the music and individual expression.
Locking emerged from the funk era of the early 1970s, embodying the spirit of individual expression and creative freedom that defined the era.
The dance became a powerful form of self-expression, allowing dancers to showcase their personality and creativity through improvised movements.

music.description: Locking is performed to funk music with strong, steady beats that provide the rhythmic foundation for the characteristic ’lock’ movements. The music’s emphasis on groove and rhythm allows dancers to play with timing and express their individual style.

artists.name: James Brown
artists.contribution: The Godfather of Soul’s rhythmic innovations provided the musical foundation that inspired early Locking dancers.

artists.name: Parliament-Funkadelic
artists.contribution: George Clinton’s funk empire created the groove-heavy soundscapes that became synonymous with West Coast funk styles.

music.playlist: Curated playlist of tracks that define Locking’s musical heritage and contemporary evolution.

techniques.title: Techniques & Key Moves
content: The fundamental ’Lock’ — the signature freeze that gives the dance its name
Points and hand gestures that emphasize the rhythmic breaks
Fast leg movements contrasted with sudden stops
Theatrical expressions and showmanship

resources.name: Campbell Lock Dance
resources.description: Official website preserving the authentic history of Locking/Campbellock

media.title: Featured Video
media.description: Showcase video demonstrating key Locking moves and techniques

content: Breaking (B-Boying/B-Girling) combines athletic floor work with rhythmic footwork, explosive power moves, and dynamic freezes. Born in 1973 Bronx block parties, breakers battle in cyphers using toprock, downrock, power, and freeze combinations.
Each breaking battle tells a story through movement, with dancers showcasing technical mastery, originality, and respect for hip-hop’s foundational culture.

summary: Breaking emerged at DJ Kool Herc’s 1973 block parties when dancers began responding to drum breaks with innovative floor work and acrobatic moves.
Pioneering crews like Rock Steady Crew and New York City Breakers developed the vocabulary of toprock, footwork, power moves, and freezes that define breaking today.
content: Breaking’s roots trace back to DJ Kool Herc’s legendary parties in 1973, where dancers responded to extended drum breaks with innovative footwork and acrobatics.
The dance evolved through friendly competition, with b-boys and b-girls showcasing originality, athleticism, and respect for the culture.

Hip-Hop dance is the foundational street style born from the cultural movement of the Bronx in the 1970s. It incorporates freestyle, social dances, and party moves, reflecting the energy and diversity of Hip-Hop culture.
The style emphasizes individuality, community, and creative expression, evolving alongside rap, DJing, and graffiti art.

summary: Hip-Hop dance developed as part of the Five Elements of Hip-Hop, blending influences from breaking, popping, locking, and social dances.
The dance’s origins lie in block parties and cyphers, where dancers innovated new moves and shared their styles with the community.
Hip-Hop continues to evolve, embracing new influences while honoring its roots in self-expression and unity.

content: Popping is a funk-driven street dance style based on quickly contracting and relaxing muscles to create sharp, robotic movements called ’pops.’ Dancers use isolations, waves, and animation to bring music to life.
Originating in Fresno, California, popping became a staple of West Coast funk styles and a favorite in battles and performances.

summary: Popping was pioneered by dancers like Boogaloo Sam and the Electric Boogaloos in the late 1970s.
The style evolved through experimentation, crew battles, and the influence of funk music legends.
content: Boogaloo Sam created popping by combining boogaloo, robot, and other funk styles, inspiring a new generation of dancers.
Popping’s versatility and creativity have made it a cornerstone of street dance culture worldwide.
House dance is a social street style that emerged in Chicago and New York clubs during the 1980s. It features fast footwork, fluid torso movements, and improvisation to house music’s driving beats.
The style celebrates freedom, musicality, and connection, thriving in underground club scenes and global dance communities.

summary: House dance developed alongside house music, with dancers innovating new steps and grooves in legendary clubs like the Warehouse and Paradise Garage.
The style spread internationally, influencing club culture and contemporary street dance.
content: Dancers like Brian ’Footwork’ Green and Ejoe Wilson helped shape house dance, blending influences from jazz, tap, and African dance.
House remains a vibrant, evolving style that values community, creativity, and the joy of movement.

Voguing is a dramatic, pose-driven dance style born from Harlem’s ballroom scene in the 1970s-80s. Dancers use angular arm movements, runway walks, and expressive poses inspired by fashion and Egyptian art.
The style is a celebration of identity, resilience, and self-expression, rooted in LGBTQ+ ballroom culture.

summary: Voguing evolved in Harlem’s ballroom competitions, where dancers competed in categories like ’Old Way,’ ’New Way,’ and ’Vogue Fem.’
The style gained mainstream attention through artists like Willi Ninja and Madonna, but its heart remains in the ballroom community.
content: Voguing’s origins are deeply tied to the struggle for acceptance and creative freedom in LGBTQ+ communities.
The dance continues to inspire new generations, blending tradition with innovation and activism.
Wh/aacking is an expressive dance style emphasizing rapid arm movements, poses, and musical interpretation. It originated in Los Angeles clubs in the 1970s, blending funk, disco, and theatricality.
The style empowers dancers to tell stories through movement, celebrating individuality and freedom.

summary: Wh/aacking was pioneered by dancers in LA’s gay club scene, including Tyrone Proctor and the Punking movement.
The style evolved through battles, performances, and the influence of disco music.
content: Wh/aacking’s roots lie in the search for self-expression and visibility within marginalized communities.
The dance remains a powerful tool for storytelling, activism, and creative exploration.
Krumping is a raw, high-energy street dance style from South Central LA, characterized by free, expressive movements and emotional intensity.
Dancers use stomps, chest pops, and arm swings to channel personal stories and spiritual connection.

summary: Krumping was created in the early 2000s by dancers like Tight Eyez and Big M, evolving from clowning and street battles.
The style became a form of release and empowerment, spreading through dance films and global competitions.
content: Krumping’s origins are rooted in resilience and community, offering dancers a way to express emotion and overcome adversity.
The dance continues to evolve, inspiring new generations to find their voice through movement.
The Hustle is a partner dance from the 1970s disco era, featuring synchronized spins, turns, and smooth footwork. It became a popular social dance in clubs and parties across New York City.
The style celebrates connection, rhythm, and the joy of dancing together.

summary: The Hustle developed alongside disco music, with dancers innovating new steps and patterns in legendary venues like Studio 54.
Dancers like Van McCoy and Billy Fajardo helped popularize the Hustle, bringing it to mainstream audiences through competitions and performances.
The dance continues to evolve, connecting generations through music and movement.

content: Punking is a theatrical street dance style from Los Angeles, emphasizing dramatic gestures, poses, and runway attitude. It originated in LA’s underground gay community and later evolved into whacking/waacking.
The style empowers dancers to embrace character, emotion, and individuality.

summary: Punking was early 1970s by dancers in LA’s underground gay club scene, including Michael Angelo Harris, Andrew Frank, and Viktor Manoel at clubs like Paradise Ballroom, Ginos, and Ginos II
The style later evolved into whacking/waacking as it spread beyond the gay community, influencing modern street dance culture.
content: Punking’s roots lie in the search for creative freedom and self-expression within marginalized LGBTQ+ communities in 1970s Los Angeles
The dance remains historically significant as the foundation that led to whacking/waacking, valuing storytelling, attitude, and innovation.
Turfing is an Oakland-born street dance style combining acrobatics, storytelling, and precise footwork. Dancers use intricate movements to create visual illusions and tell personal stories.
The style celebrates creativity, resilience, and the power of movement to inspire change.

summary: Turfing emerged in the 2000s in Oakland, California, as dancers responded to local music and social challenges with innovative movement.
The style gained recognition through viral videos, battles, and the influence of crews like Turf Feinz.
content: Turfing’s origins are deeply tied to community, activism, and the desire to uplift through dance.
The dance continues to evolve, inspiring new generations to push creative boundaries and tell their stories.
Litefeet, also known as ’getting lite,’ is a dynamic street dance style from Harlem characterized by intricate footwork and weightless movement that makes dancers appear to have ’light feet.’
The style emerged from New York’s subway culture where dancers perform ’Showtime’ on moving trains, combining athletic skill with urban storytelling.

summary: Litefeet emerged from Harlem in the early 2000s (established in 2006), growing from subway performances and street culture.
The style gained recognition through viral videos and the unique ’Showtime’ performances on NYC subway cars.
content: Litefeet developed as a response to urban life, with dancers creating a weightless, fluid style that could be performed in confined spaces like subway cars.
The dance became a symbol of Harlem’s resilient street culture, spreading through social media and underground dance battles.
Chicago Footwork, also known as juke in its earlier development, is a dance culture and electronic music genre that emerged in Chicago in the mid-1980s, originally performed to ghetto house music.
By the early 1990s, footwork had evolved to be performed at 160 beats per minute, featuring intricate juke-style combinations and explosive movements that define the genre.

summary: Chicago Footwork originated in the mid-1980s from ghetto house culture, with key developments by House-O-Matic’s and later by Anthony ’Ant’ Brown.
The juke/footwork style evolved from individual moves to complex combinations, with battle groups like Wolfpak and The Phirm emerging in the 1990s.
content: Footwork traces back to the legendary dance group House-O-Matic’s on Chicago’s Southside, where dancers like Calvin, Goose, and Michael Stamps developed ’Dance Group Footwork’ in 1988-1989.

Anthony ’Ant’ Brown created the foundational ’Erk N Jerkz’ step in the early 1990s, training dancers in ’The Dungeon’ basement and revolutionizing the juke style into the intricate combinations we know today.
Detroit Jit is a street dance style originating in the 1970s with the Jitterbugs, characterized by explosive footwork that emphasizes feet hitting the air rather than the dancefloor.
The style features quick, jerky movements with restricted upper body motion, performed to ghettotech music at around 150 BPM.

summary: Detroit Jit began in the 1970s with the Jitterbugs and developed alongside Detroit’s electronic music scene, particularly ghettotech.
The style represents Detroit’s unique urban dance culture, with battle crews competing against each other and Chicago Footwork dancers.
content: Jit emerged from Detroit’s street culture in the 1970s, developing its distinctive style of explosive, fast-paced movements that make dancers appear to defy gravity.
The dance culture struggled with mainstream recognition, as noted by promoter Martez Claybren, but maintains a strong underground scene and remains central to Detroit’s annual music festivals.
Soul Dance (also known as Soul Step) is a Japanese party-oriented dance style that emerged from inspiration by the US television show Soul Train and the broader soul music culture.
The style was popularized by influential Japanese dancers like MOGA and Yoshie, who adapted the energetic, individual expression of Soul Train dancing for Japanese club and party scenes.

summary: Soul Dance developed in Japan as dancers were inspired by Soul Train’s vibrant dance culture, creating their own interpretation of the energetic, freestyle party dancing.
Key figures like MOGA and Yoshie became prominent ambassadors of the style, helping establish Soul Dance as a distinct element of Japanese street dance culture.
content: The Japanese Soul Dance scene emerged as dancers drew inspiration from the iconic American TV show Soul Train, adapting its celebratory, individual expression style for Japanese audiences.
While connected to Japan’s broader underground Northern Soul scene in cities like Kobe, Soul Dance became its own distinct party-oriented style emphasizing fun, energy, and personal expression.

hero.subtitle: From breaking to voguing, explore the rich tapestry of movement that defines street dance culture.

overview.title: THE COMPLETE COLLECTION
overview.description: Dive deep into the authentic styles that shaped street dance culture. From the foundational to the revolutionary, each movement tells a story of creativity and community.
overview.content: These dance styles represent decades of cultural innovation, community building, and artistic expression. Each carries its own history, techniques, and values that continue to evolve with new generations of dancers.

allStyles.title: DANCE STYLES
allStyles.description: Explore the styles in our comprehensive archive, organized alphabetically with cultural context and historical significance.

cta.title: Start Your Journey
cta.description: Choose a style that speaks to you and begin exploring the rich world of street dance culture.

seo.title: Complete Street Dance Styles Archive - Hip-Hop to House
seo.description: Explore authentic street dance styles from breaking to voguing, popping to krumping. Discover the history, moves, and culture behind each dance style with video tutorials and community stories.
seo.keywords: street dance styles, hip hop dance, breaking b-boying, popping animation, campbellock locking funk styles, house dance, voguing ballroom, wh/aacking punking, krumping clowning, street dance history, urban dance culture, dance battles, freestyle dance, street dance tutorials, dance community

theLock.name: The Lock
theLock.description: The foundational Locking move — a sudden freeze or stop that punctuates motion and creates rhythmic contrast.

points.name: Points
points.description: Hand and arm gestures that accentuate musical breaks and direct attention during performance.

funk.name: Funk
funk.description: Groove-driven music with strong backbeats that provided the rhythmic foundation for Locking and many West Coast styles.

shortDescriptions.breaking: Athletic floor work combining toprock, footwork, power moves, and freezes.
shortDescriptions.hipHop: The foundational street dance that emerged from Hip-Hop culture in the 1970s.
shortDescriptions.popping: Street dance style based on quickly contracting and relaxing muscles.
shortDescriptions.locking: Funk-based dance style characterized by distinctive arm and hand movements.
shortDescriptions.house: Social dance style that emerged with house music in Chicago and New York.
shortDescriptions.voguing: Ballroom culture dance inspired by fashion poses and Egyptian hieroglyphs.
shortDescriptions.waacking: Expressive dance style emphasizing arm movements and poses, born from LA club culture.
shortDescriptions.krumping: High-energy, expressive dance from LA characterized by free, expressive movements.
shortDescriptions.hustle: Partner dance from 1970s disco era, featuring synchronized spins and turns.
shortDescriptions.punking: LA-originated style from the underground gay community, the foundation that evolved into whacking/waacking.
shortDescriptions.turfing: Oakland-born dance style combining acrobatics, storytelling, and precise footwork.
shortDescriptions.litefeet: Harlem street dance with intricate footwork and weightless movement, popularized on NYC subways.
shortDescriptions.footwork: Chicago juke/footwork culture that evolved from ghetto house in the mid-1980s, featuring intricate footwork combinations performed at 160 BPM.
shortDescriptions.jit: Detroit street dance originating in the 1970s with the Jitterbugs, emphasizing feet hitting the air with explosive, fast-paced movements to ghettotech music.
shortDescriptions.soul: Japanese party dance style inspired by Soul Train, popularized by dancers like MOGA and Yoshie, featuring energetic movements and individual expression.

lockingFeatured.title: Time Travel: A Tribute to Don "Campbellock" Campbell
lockingFeatured.description: Directed, edited, and animated by Mathilde Chamussy. Using live footage of Don Campbellock Campbell.

toniBasilMemories.title: Toni Basil Sharing Memories for The Lockers
toniBasilMemories.description: Toni Basil shares her personal memories and experiences with The Lockers, providing intimate insights into the early days of locking and the legendary dance crew.

punkingFeatured.title: PUNKING/Whacking/Waacking originators by IHOAP
punkingFeatured.description: This video presents originators/innovators of PUNKING/WHacking/Waacking dance style.

tyroneProctor.title: Interview with Tyrone Proctor - Rest In Power Tyrone
tyroneProctor.description: An interview with Tyrone Proctor, one of the Pioneers of Waacking and an original Soul Train Dancer. Interview courtesy of Rennie Harris and the American Street Dance Archives. Filmed at Destiny Arts Center in Oakland, CA during Rennie Harris’ Illadelph Legends Hip Hop Festival Bay Area, presented by Embodiment Project.

marjorySmarth.title: In Remembrance and Honor of Marjory Smarth
marjorySmarth.description: A tribute video honoring Marjory Smarth, a beloved figure in the house dance community. #LiveTrueDanceFree #MarjorySmarthForever

scorpionLopez.title: Scorpion - On Lopez Tonight
scorpionLopez.description: Scorpion showcases his incredible turfing skills on Lopez Tonight, demonstrating the athleticism and storytelling power of Oakland’s signature dance style.

liquidFlow.title: Liquid Flow - A Viral Moment, Born From Grief: The Story of the TURF FEINZ
liquidFlow.description: In "Liquid Flow," a 2019 mini-documentary produced for the Oakland Museum of California (OMCA) featuring the Turf Feinz and directed by YAK Films, Darrell "D-Real" Armstead says, "Oakland is a city of artists. Layer on layer. That pressure, the need to express yourself? It’s everywhere. Homicide. Housing. Money flowing out but never in. Somebody you know dead. Some people say all this, that we do now, came from all that."

birth.title: The Birth of Hip Hop
birth.description: In 1973, DJ Kool Herc set up his turntables and introduced a technique at a South Bronx house party that would change music as many people knew it. His ability to switch from record to record — as well as isolate and repeat music breaks — led to the discovery of the hip hop genre.

interview.title: Interview with Popin Pete & Suga Pop
interview.description: The EB’s were born in 1977 when Boogaloo Sam founded the Electronic Boogaloo Lockers - Dance Channel TV interviews Popin Pete & Suga Pop.

lgbtqHistory.title: How the LGBTQ community created voguing
lgbtqHistory.description: Vogue, the dance, not the magazine. Explore the origins of voguing in the LGBTQ ballroom community and how this powerful form of expression emerged from Harlem’s underground scene.

parisIsBurning.title: Paris is Burning
parisIsBurning.description: The iconic 1990 documentary that brought ballroom culture and voguing to mainstream consciousness, chronicling the drag ball scene in New York City during the 1980s.

strikeAPose.title: Strike a Pose
strikeAPose.description: Documentary following Madonna’s backup dancers from the Blond Ambition tour, exploring how voguing entered mainstream culture and the lives of the dancers who helped popularize it worldwide.

featured.title: Chicago Footwork Dance Battle
featured.description: Witness the explosive energy and intricate footwork combinations of Chicago’s juke/footwork culture in this intense dance battle showcase.

letMeSee.title: Let Me See Your Footwork
letMeSee.description: A dynamic demonstration of Chicago footwork techniques and the cultural significance of juke music in the dance community.

pioneers.title: Detroit OG’s - Pioneers of the Jit: The Jitterbugs (Trailer)
pioneers.description: A documentary trailer exploring the pioneers of Detroit Jit, tracing the origins back to the Jitterbugs and the evolution of this unique Motor City dance style.

tommyClown.title: History of Tommy the Clown - The Godfather of Krumping
tommyClown.description: Get to know Thomas Johnson, the king of clowning, the godfather of krumping, and the leader of the T-Squad.

latinOrigins.title: The Latin Hustle Origins
latinOrigins.description: Puerto Rican teenagers from the South Bronx created the Latin Hustle in 1972, establishing a foundational partner dance that would define the disco era.

yoshieFeatured.title: YOSHIE - SOUL DANCE "Inner City Blues / Make Me Wanna Holler" 【DANCEWORKS】
yoshieFeatured.description: A masterful performance by YOSHIE, one of the key figures in Japanese Soul Dance, showcasing the style’s energetic expression to classic soul music.

soundOfSubway.title: Litefeet: Sound of the Subway
soundOfSubway.description: FACT presents Litefeet: Sound of the Subway, a documentary on the music of the New York underground.

danceStyleDescriptions.hipHop: The foundational street dance that emerged from Hip-Hop culture in the 1970s.
danceStyleDescriptions.breaking: Athletic floor work combining toprock, footwork, power moves, and freezes.
danceStyleDescriptions.popping: Sharp, rhythmic contractions and releases creating robotic and animated movements.
danceStyleDescriptions.locking: Funk-based dance style characterized by distinctive arm and hand movements.
danceStyleDescriptions.house: Fluid footwork and torso movements that emerged with Chicago house music.
danceStyleDescriptions.voguing: Fashion-inspired poses and runway walks from Harlem ballroom culture.
danceStyleDescriptions.waacking: Expressive dance style emphasizing arm movements and poses, born from LA club culture.
danceStyleDescriptions.punking: Theatrical dance style from LA’s underground gay community that later evolved into whacking/waacking.
danceStyleDescriptions.krumping: High-energy movement expressing raw emotions and spiritual connection.
danceStyleDescriptions.clowning: Playful dance style that evolved into krumping, emphasizing character and comedy.
danceStyleDescriptions.juke-footwork: Lightning-fast leg work synchronized to Chicago juke music.
danceStyleDescriptions.flexing: Bone-bending contortionist style from Brooklyn’s underground scene.
danceStyleDescriptions.litefeet: New York street dance characterized by intricate footwork and upper body flow.
danceStyleDescriptions.animation: Robotic style emphasizing isolation and mechanical movements.
danceStyleDescriptions.boogaloo: Original style of the Electric Boogaloos crew with flowing, funky movements.
danceStyleDescriptions.strutting: Smooth, sophisticated funk style with emphasis on attitude and groove.
danceStyleDescriptions.hustle: Partner dance that became a popular social dance in the disco era.
danceStyleDescriptions.chicago-footwork: Fast-paced footwork style from Chicago’s house music scene.
danceStyleDescriptions.jersey-club: High-energy dance from New Jersey’s club music culture.
danceStyleDescriptions.afrobeats: Contemporary African dance styles influenced by traditional and modern music.
danceStyleDescriptions.dancehall: Jamaican dance style with strong cultural roots and social significance.
danceStyleDescriptions.soca: Caribbean dance celebrating life and culture through rhythmic movement.
danceStyleDescriptions.capoeira: Brazilian martial art that blends dance, acrobatics, and music.
danceStyleDescriptions.turfing: Oakland-born dance style combining acrobatics, storytelling, and precise footwork.

donCampbell.name: Don “Campbellock” Campbell
donCampbell.bio: Born 1951. Pioneered Campbellock (Locking) in LA in 1970. Known for theatrical freezes, funk-timed locks, and individual expression.

toniBasil.name: Toni Basil
toniBasil.bio: Choreographer and performer who helped popularize Locking through The Lockers and mainstream media appearances in the 1970s.

fredBerry.name: Fred “Rerun” Berry
fredBerry.bio: Fred Berry (“Rerun”) was a prominent performer and cultural figure who helped bring West Coast funk styles, including Locking, to wider attention through TV and stage performances.

djKoolHerc.name: DJ Kool Herc
djKoolHerc.bio: Jamaican-American DJ who pioneered hip-hop music and culture through his block parties in the South Bronx, introducing the breakbeat technique that became the foundation of hip-hop.

grandmasterFlash.name: Grandmaster Flash
grandmasterFlash.bio: Pioneer DJ known for developing turntable techniques like the backspin and crossfading, revolutionizing DJ culture and laying the groundwork for modern hip-hop production.

afrikaBambaataa.name: Afrika Bambaataa
afrikaBambaataa.bio: Hip-hop pioneer who founded the Universal Zulu Nation and added the fifth element ’Knowledge’ to hip-hop, emphasizing education and community building.

grandmasterCaz.name: Grandmaster Caz
grandmasterCaz.bio: Early MC known for his complex rhyme schemes and lyrical innovation, helping to evolve MCing from simple party hosting into sophisticated rap storytelling.

melleMel.name: Melle Mel
melleMel.bio: Pioneering rapper known for socially conscious lyrics and powerful delivery, bringing depth and message to hip-hop music through tracks like ’The Message’.

kurtisBlow.name: Kurtis Blow
kurtisBlow.bio: First commercially successful rapper to sign with a major label, helping to bring hip-hop from the streets to mainstream audiences with hits like ’The Breaks’.

crazyLegs.name: Crazy Legs
crazyLegs.bio: Legendary b-boy and founder of Rock Steady Crew, known for his powerful breaking style and role in defining b-boy culture and competitions.

kenSwift.name: Ken Swift
kenSwift.bio: Innovative b-boy known for his dynamic moves and contributions to the evolution of breaking, particularly in power moves and floor work.

babyLove.name: Baby Love
babyLove.bio: Trailblazing female b-girl who broke barriers in the male-dominated breaking scene, known for her technical skill and competitive spirit.

darrylCornbreadMcCray.name: Darryl “Cornbread” McCray
darrylCornbreadMcCray.bio: Early graffiti pioneer from Philadelphia who helped establish tagging as a form of urban expression, influencing the development of modern graffiti art.

taki183.name: TAKI 183
taki183.bio: Greek-American graffiti writer whose widespread tags in New York City brought graffiti to mainstream attention, inspiring a generation of urban artists.

phase2.name: Phase 2
phase2.bio: Graffiti pioneer known for developing the bubble letter style and complex lettering techniques that revolutionized graffiti art and typography.

ladyPink.name: Lady Pink
ladyPink.bio: One of the first prominent female graffiti artists, known for her detailed pieces and role in bringing women into the graffiti movement.

krsOne.name: KRS-One
krsOne.bio: Conscious rapper and activist known for educational approach to hip-hop, founding the Temple of Hip-Hop and emphasizing knowledge as the fifth element.

gregPope.name: Greg “Campbellock Jr.” Pope
gregPope.bio: Greg Pope, known as “Campbellock Jr.”, was one of the original seven members of The Lockers from 1973-1976, contributing to the crew’s groundbreaking television appearances.

adolfoQuinones.name: Adolfo “Shabba Doo” Quiñones
adolfoQuinones.bio: Adolfo Quiñones, professionally known as “Shabba Doo”, was an original member of The Lockers and later gained international fame starring in the “Breakin’” film series.

billWilliams.name: William “Slim the Robot” Williams
billWilliams.bio: William “Bill” Williams, performing as “Slim the Robot”, was one of the original seven Lockers members known for his robotic movement style and innovative choreography.

leoWilliamson.name: Leo “Fluky Luke” Williamson
leoWilliamson.bio: Leo Williamson, known as “Fluky Luke”, was an original member of The Lockers from 1973-1976, known for his smooth style and contributions to the crew’s early success.

andrewFrank.name: Andrew Frank
andrewFrank.bio: Recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

arthurGoff.name: Arthur Goff
arthurGoff.bio: Recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

tinkerToy.name: Tinker Toy
tinkerToy.bio: Recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

billyStarrEstrada.name: Billy Starr Estrada
billyStarrEstrada.bio: Known as ’Billy Starr’, recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

lonnyCarbajal.name: Lonny Carbajal
lonnyCarbajal.bio: Known as ’Lonnie Carbajial’, recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

viktorManoel.name: Viktor Manoel
viktorManoel.bio: Born 1957 in Mexico. Mexican-American dancer, choreographer, writer, and actor who was one of the original Punking pioneers. Later worked with renowned choreographers including Toni Basil and Édouard Lock, and performed in David Bowie’s Glass Spider Tour (1987). Appeared in films including ’Staying Alive’ (1983) and ’Breakin’ 2: Electric Boogaloo’ (1984).

tommyMitchell.name: Tommy Mitchell
tommyMitchell.bio: Known as ’Little Tommy’, recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

fayeRaye.name: Faye Raye
fayeRaye.bio: Recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

kennyChinaDoll.name: Kenny “China Doll”
kennyChinaDoll.bio: Recognized by Tyrone Proctor as one of the wonderful geniuses of waacking/punking in the underground clubs of 1970s Los Angeles.

michaelAngeloHarris.name: Michael Angelo Harris
michaelAngeloHarris.bio: The innovative DJ who provided the musical foundation for the Punking art form and movement in the 1970s Los Angeles gay club scene.

tyroneProctor.name: Tyrone “The Bone” Proctor
tyroneProctor.bio: Legendary dancer nicknamed “The Bone” by Don Cornelius, Tyrone Proctor is one of the last living pioneers of Waacking, which he helped evolve in 1970s Los Angeles gay club scene. Original Soul Train Gang dancer who won the 1975 American Bandstand competition with partner Sharon Hill. Co-founded The Outrageous Waack Dancers with Jeffrey Daniel, Jodi Watley, and others. Featured in Jodi Watley’s “Still A Thrill” (1987) - the first major music video to feature waacking. Helped form Breed Of Motion in NYC with Willi Ninja, and choreographed for Taylor Dane’s “Tell It To My Heart” - the first video to incorporate Vogue style. Nominated “Best Choreographer” at 1989 MTV Awards for New Kids on the Block.

jeffreyDaniel.name: Jeffrey Daniel
jeffreyDaniel.bio: Born August 24, 1955. American dancer, singer-songwriter, and choreographer who learned Waacking from Tyrone Proctor and added the ’g’ to make it ’waacking’. Founding member of Shalamar and taught Michael Jackson the moonwalk. Worked as choreographer on Michael Jackson’s ’Bad’ and ’Smooth Criminal’ videos.

archieBurnett.name: Archie Burnett
archieBurnett.bio: Influential dancer and instructor known for his contributions to both Waacking and Voguing styles, helping to preserve and teach these dance forms to new generations.

billyGoodson.name: Billy Goodson
billyGoodson.bio: Member of the legendary ’Outrageous Waack Dancers’ who helped define and showcase the Waacking style in its formative years.

jodyWatley.name: Jody Watley
jodyWatley.bio: Born January 30, 1959. Grammy Award-winning singer, dancer, and style icon who started as a Soul Train dancer alongside Jeffrey Daniel before co-founding Shalamar. Her dance background and fashion sense helped bring street dance aesthetics to mainstream pop culture.

sharonHill.name: Sharon Hill
sharonHill.bio: Pioneer dancer who contributed to the development and preservation of Waacking culture in Los Angeles.

clevelandMosesJr.name: Cleveland Moses Jr
clevelandMosesJr.bio: Influential figure in the early Waacking scene who helped shape the style and pass it on to future generations.

kirtWashington.name: Kirt Washington
kirtWashington.bio: Pioneer dancer who was instrumental in the development and evolution of Waacking in Los Angeles dance culture.

williNinja.name: Willi Ninja
williNinja.bio: Born April 12, 1961, died September 2, 2006. William Roscoe Leake, known as Willi Ninja, was the ’Godfather of Voguing’ who founded the House of Ninja in 1982, one of the early and most influential Houses in the ballroom scene. Featured prominently in the documentary ’Paris Is Burning’, he refined voguing with clean, sharp movements and brought ballroom culture to mainstream attention through music videos with Janet Jackson and runway work coaching supermodels and celebrities on their walks.

parisDupree.name: Paris Dupree
parisDupree.bio: A widely acknowledged pioneer of voguing who is credited with coining the term ’voguing’ by mimicking poses from Vogue magazine during a competitive exchange with other queens at an after-hours club. Dupree’s pioneering role in bringing the style of posing to the forefront eventually became known as voguing, though the precise origin is debated, their influence as a foundational figure is widely recognized.

joseXtravaganza.name: Jose Xtravaganza
joseXtravaganza.bio: Member of the influential Xtravaganza family in the ballroom scene, Jose Xtravaganza was one of the pioneers who helped bring ballroom culture to mainstream attention, notably dancing with Madonna and contributing to the global spread of voguing and ballroom culture.

luisXtravaganza.name: Luis Xtravaganza
luisXtravaganza.bio: Member of the influential Xtravaganza family in the ballroom scene, Luis Xtravaganza was one of the pioneers who helped bring ballroom culture to mainstream attention, notably dancing with Madonna and contributing to the global spread of voguing and ballroom culture.

williamDorseySwann.name: William Dorsey Swann
williamDorseySwann.bio: A pioneer of early ballroom culture in the 19th century, William Dorsey Swann’s ’Cake Walk’ traditions influenced the early development of the drag scene and ballroom culture. According to the National Museums Liverpool, Swann’s contributions laid important groundwork for what would evolve into modern ballroom and voguing culture.

frankieKnuckles.name: Frankie Knuckles
frankieKnuckles.bio: Widely regarded as the ’Godfather of House Music,’ Frankie Knuckles was instrumental in developing the house music sound at Chicago’s Warehouse club. His innovative mixing style and music selection created the foundation for house dance culture.

larryLevan.name: Larry Levan
larryLevan.bio: Legendary DJ at New York’s Paradise Garage, Larry Levan’s mixing style and music selection heavily influenced the development of house dance. His sets created the perfect environment for the fluid, soulful movements that define house dance.

marjorySmarth.name: Marjory “Lotus” Smarth
marjorySmarth.bio: A beloved figure from Haiti via NYC who was one of the few prominent women in the early house scene. Renowned for her joyful style and generosity in mentoring younger dancers, Marjory’s influence is still felt after her passing. Featured in the documentary ’Check Your Body at the Door’ and lived by the motto ’Live True, Dance Free.’

ejoeWilson.name: Ejoe Wilson
ejoeWilson.bio: A respected house dance instructor and choreographer, Ejoe Wilson has been instrumental in preserving and teaching authentic house dance techniques. He’s known for his deep understanding of house music and its connection to movement.

brianFootworkGreen.name: Brian “Footwork” Green
brianFootworkGreen.bio: An instrumental figure in codifying house dance, Brian is famous for his incredibly fast and precise footwork (hence the nickname) and for teaching house dance globally. In the 1990s and 2000s he organized events (like House Dance Conference) and helped introduce formal teaching of house steps.

caleafSellers.name: Caleaf “Big Leaf” Sellers
caleafSellers.bio: Part of the famed MOP TOP crew in NYC, Caleaf is known for his musicality and helped innovate many house steps. He, along with others like Brooklyn Terry Wright and Buddha Stretch, bridged hip-hop and house communities.

kimHolmes.name: Kim D. Holmes
kimHolmes.bio: A versatile dancer who brought her background in hip-hop, jazz, and African dance into house. Kim was a fixture in the NYC clubs and is respected as a mentor in the house dance community.

brahmsLaFortune.name: Brahms Bravo La Fortune
brahmsLaFortune.bio: A pioneering figure in house dance who has contributed to the development and spread of house dance culture through teaching and performance.

shanSelby.name: Shan Selby
shanSelby.bio: Also known as Shan S, a pioneering dancer who was instrumental in the early development of house dance culture and helped establish its foundational movements.

rennieHarris.name: Rennie Harris
rennieHarris.bio: An influential choreographer and dancer who has made significant contributions to hip-hop and street dance culture, including connections to house dance through his work in urban dance forms.

ronHardy.name: Ron Hardy
ronHardy.bio: A DJ at Chicago’s The Music Box (a successor to The Warehouse), Hardy played a crucial role in developing the genre’s trajectory. He was known for playing the rawest, wildest rhythm tracks and was the DJ to whom producers brought their latest tracks to test crowd reactions.

jamiePrinciple.name: Jamie Principle
jamiePrinciple.bio: Created ’Waiting On Your Angel’, which was one of the most influential early house tracks in Chicago. His work on cassette was so popular that it inspired numerous other producers and helped establish the foundation of house music.

jesseSaunders.name: Jesse Saunders
jesseSaunders.bio: Recognized for producing ’On & On,’ the first widely considered house music track. Jesse was instrumental in the early development of house music production in Chicago and helped establish the foundational sound of the genre.

larryHeard.name: Larry “Mr. Fingers” Heard
larryHeard.bio: Known for his work as Mr. Fingers, Larry Heard is a key figure among the foundational pioneers of house music. His deep, soulful productions helped define the genre’s emotional and musical depth.

marshallJefferson.name: Marshall Jefferson
marshallJefferson.bio: An influential producer, Jefferson was one of the five pioneers who laid the groundwork for house music. He created ’Move Your Body’ (1986), the first house song to use piano, and his deep house productions include work with CeCe Rogers, Sterling Void, and Ten City’s first two albums.

adonis.name: Adonis
adonis.bio: A significant artist who helped shape the sound and development of house music. Created the classic ’No Way Back’ and was one of the early producers on the Chicago house scene, with his tracks becoming hugely influential in defining the raw Chicago house sound.

steveSilkHurley.name: Steve “Silk” Hurley
steveSilkHurley.bio: Created ’Jack Your Body’ which became a Number One hit in the UK in 1987, bringing house music to mainstream attention. Founded DJ International Records with Rocky Jones.

lilLouis.name: Lil Louis
lilLouis.bio: Created the legendary ’French Kiss’ which climbed to Number 2 in the charts. Known for his innovative approach to house music and for throwing notorious parties in Chicago.

farleyJackmasterFunk.name: Farley ’Jackmaster’ Funk
farleyJackmasterFunk.bio: Secured a spot on Chicago’s WBMX radio station, playing house music after midnight and bringing in the Hot Mix 5. His radio shows were crucial to spreading house music culture.

tonyHumphries.name: Tony Humphries
tonyHumphries.bio: Legendary DJ at New Jersey’s Zanzibar Club since 1982 and on New York’s Kiss FM since 1981. Tony was instrumental in developing the Jersey garage sound that married r’n’b-based dance to house music.

tonyMcgregor.name: Tony McGregor
tonyMcgregor.bio: One of the hundreds of phenomenal dancers who was key in the early progression of house dance in the social dance scene and instrumental in introducing house dance culture across the globe.

brooklynTerryWright.name: Terry “Brooklyn” Wright
brooklynTerryWright.bio: A pioneering house dancer from Brooklyn who was instrumental in the early development and spread of house dance culture across the globe during its formative years.

shannonMabra.name: Shannon “Which Way” Mabra
shannonMabra.bio: One of the innovators who were key in developing house dance and sharing it worldwide. Known as ’Which Way’ Mabra, he contributed his own unique flavor to the evolution of the dance during its formative years.

tonySekouWilliams.name: Tony “Sekou” Williams
tonySekouWilliams.bio: One of the innovators who contributed his own distinctive flavor to house dance development, particularly known for his athletic lofting moves. Featured in ’Check Your Body at the Door’ documentary and helped spread house dance culture worldwide.

voodooRay.name: Voodoo Ray
voodooRay.bio: One of the innovators known for his party organizing and charismatic presence that helped keep the house dance scene vibrant. Contributed his own unique flavor to developing the dance and sharing it worldwide.

hiro.name: Hiroyuki “Hiro” Suzuki
hiro.bio: Japanese house dance pioneer who helped bring house dance culture to Japan and Asia. Known for his technical skill and dedication to preserving the authentic spirit of house dance while introducing it to new communities.

mamson.name: Mamé “Mamson” Diarra
mamson.bio: Second generation member of Wanted Posse (joined 1999) and co-founder of Serial Stepperz. Mamson is a globally recognized house dancer, choreographer, and teacher from France. Known for blending other street dance styles like breaking and new jack swing into his house dancing, helping to create a distinctly French approach to house dance.

babson.name: Ousmane “Babson” Sy
babson.bio: Member of Wanted Posse from 1995-2020 and co-founder of Serial Stepperz. Babson was celebrated for his profound impact on house dance, pioneering the ’Afro-house’ style by incorporating traditional African dances like Sabar and Pantsula. His innovative fusion work helped define the French approach to house dance culture.

yugson.name: Massangila “Yugson” Lumengo
yugson.bio: Member of Wanted Posse and founding member of Serial Stepperz. Yugson brought expertise from hip-hop, new jack swing, and breaking to his house style, helping to elevate house dance from a club-based social dance to a respected art form performed in international competitions.

babyson.name: Soria “Babyson” Rem
babyson.bio: Member of Wanted Posse crew, part of the pioneering French dance collective that created the distinctive ’melt’hip hop’ style mixing breakdance, house, and traditional influences.

badson.name: Bahassane “Badson” Ahmada
badson.bio: Founder of Wanted Posse crew in 1993, creator of the pioneering French dance collective that developed the distinctive ’melt’hip hop’ style mixing African dances, pantsula, tap dance, breakdance, and house music influences.

hagson.name: Hagson
hagson.bio: Founding member of Wanted Posse first generation (1993-1995), one of the original pioneers who helped create the distinctive French dance collective's revolutionary "melt hip hop" style.

kimson.name: Kimson
kimson.bio: First generation member of Wanted Posse (1993-1995), part of the original collective that established the crew's groundbreaking approach to French street dance culture.

buddhaStretch.name: Buddha Stretch
buddhaStretch.bio: Emilio Austin Jr., founding member and choreographer of Elite Force crew (1992). Helped establish house dance in mainstream hip-hop culture through music video choreography, notably Michael Jackson's "Remember the Time" (1992).

henryLink.name: Link
henryLink.bio: Henry McMillan, founding member of Elite Force crew alongside Buddha Stretch and Loose Joint. Helped establish the crew's signature style in the early 1990s Brooklyn house scene.

looseJoint.name: Loose Joint
looseJoint.bio: Jamel Brown, founding member of Elite Force crew. Known for his smooth and fluid house dance style that helped define the crew's early aesthetic and Brooklyn house movement.

bobbyBarnette.name: Mileage
bobbyBarnette.bio: Bobby Barnette, Elite Force crew member who joined in 1998. Brought his unique style and energy to the legendary house dance collective during their continued evolution.

theLockers.name: The Lockers
theLockers.description: An original Locking crew formed in the early 1970s that popularized Campbellock on television and stage; notable members included Don Campbell, Toni Basil, Fred ’Rerun’ Berry, and others.

breedOfMotion.name: Breed of Motion
breedOfMotion.description: Innovative dance collective formed by Tyrone Proctor and other pioneers in the early 1980s in New York. Featured prominent dancers including Archie Burnett and Willi Ninja, the group was instrumental in the evolution of waacking, punking, and contemporary black street dance culture. They performed and choreographed for TV shows and music acts like the Isley Brothers and New Kids on the Block, helping bridge ballroom, waacking, and mainstream entertainment.

outrageousWaackDancers.name: Outrageous Waack Dancers
outrageousWaackDancers.description: Legendary waacking crew formed in 1970s Los Angeles, featuring pioneers like Tyrone Proctor, Jeffrey Daniel, Jody Watley, Billy Goodson, Sharon Hill, Cleveland Moses Jr, and Kirt Washington. This influential collective helped define and showcase the Waacking style during its formative years, with members performing on Soul Train and contributing to the evolution of the dance form.

houseOfXtravaganza.name: House of Xtravaganza
houseOfXtravaganza.description: One of the legendary ballroom houses established in 1980s New York, founded by Hector Xtravaganza. The House of Xtravaganza became renowned for producing exceptional voguing talent including Jose and Luis Xtravaganza, who helped define and elevate the artform through their performances and teaching.

danceFloor.name: Dance Floor
danceFloor.description: A prominent house dance crew from New York established in the 1990s. According to house dance documentation, Dance Floor was instrumental in preserving and promoting authentic house dance culture during the genre’s evolution.

eliteForce.name: Elite Force
eliteForce.description: A documented house dance crew that emerged from the New York house scene. Elite Force has been recognized for maintaining the connection between house music and dance, representing the culture in competitions and showcases.

schemeTeam.name: The Scheme Team
schemeTeam.description: According to Wikipedia and the Los Angeles house dance scene documentation from the ’Pump It Up’ television series hosted by Dee Barnes, The Scheme Team was one of the crews instrumental to house dance culture in Los Angeles during the 1980s.

clubHouse.name: Club House
clubHouse.description: According to Wikipedia and the Los Angeles house dance scene documentation from the ’Pump It Up’ television series hosted by Dee Barnes, Club House was one of the crews instrumental to house dance culture in Los Angeles during the 1980s.

mopTop.name: MOP TOP
mopTop.description: Legendary NYC house dance crew from the 1990s featuring influential dancers like Caleaf Sellers, Buddha Stretch, and others. MOP TOP was instrumental in bridging hip-hop and house dance communities, helping to define the New York house scene with their innovative style and musicality.

danceFusion.name: Dance Fusion NYC
danceFusion.description: Premier New York dance collective founded in 1997, featuring legendary dancers including Caleaf Sellers, Marjory Smarth, Tony Sekou Williams, Shannon Mabra, Shannon Selby, Tony McGregor, and Hiroyuki Suzuki. Key innovators in the evolution of Hip-Hop and House Dance culture who fused hip-hop foundation with underground house dance. Performed with artists like Michael Jackson, Diana Ross, Mariah Carey, Will Smith, and LL Cool J. Known for spreading dance styles globally through teaching, judging international competitions (Juste Debout, Dance Delight), and workshops worldwide. Originally taught at historic Fazil's Dance Studio before moving to Broadway Dance Center and Peridance Capezio Center.

houseNation.name: House Nation
houseNation.description: A prominent house dance collective that played a significant role in spreading house dance culture globally. House Nation was known for organizing events, battles, and workshops that helped maintain the connection between house music and dance.

ghostShadow.name: Ghost Shadow
ghostShadow.description: NYC-based house dance crew known for their underground presence and dedication to preserving the authentic spirit of house dance. Ghost Shadow represented the raw, club-oriented style of house dancing.

exclusiveElements.name: Exclusive Elements
exclusiveElements.description: House dance crew from New York that gained recognition for their unique style and contributions to the house dance community. Exclusive Elements helped bridge different generations of house dancers through competitions and showcases.

supernaturalz.name: Supernaturz
supernaturalz.description: International house dance crew with members across different continents. Supernaturz has been influential in spreading house dance culture worldwide through workshops, battles, and performances, maintaining strong connections to the New York house scene origins.

wantedPosse.name: Wanted Posse
wantedPosse.description: Pioneering French dance crew founded in 1993 by Ahmada Bahassane in Paris. Known for their unique style mixing hip-hop, house, and breakdance with unusual musical influences. World champions at Battle Of The Year 2001 in Germany. The crew evolved from underground battles to artistic maturity, creating the distinctive ’melt’hip hop’ style incorporating African dances, pantsula, and tap dance.

serialStepperz.name: Serial Stepperz
serialStepperz.description: Influential French house dance crew formed as a sub-crew of Wanted Posse. Founded by Mamson, Babson, and Yugson, Serial Stepperz revolutionized house dance by integrating hip-hop, breaking, and African dance elements, creating the distinctly French approach to house dance and pioneering the ’Afro-house’ style.

5ElementsOfHipHop.title: 5 Elements of Hip-Hop
5ElementsOfHipHop.description: A quick conversation about the elements of Hip Hop and why it’s important to know about the cultural aspect.

djEvolution.title: The Evolution of the DJ
djEvolution.description: ABC News’ Megan Ryte reports on the evolution of the DJ in Hip-Hop and speaks with DJs about its humble beginnings in the Bronx and those who’ve helped DJ’s evolve into today’s creative force.

mcingHistory.title: Early History of The MC
mcingHistory.description: Discover how MCing evolved from party hosting into the powerful art of rap and storytelling

breakingDocumentary.title: How the Bronx brought breaking to the world
breakingDocumentary.description: A documentary exploring the origins of breaking in the Bronx and its rise to global recognition.

graffitiArt.title: A history of graffiti in NYC
graffitiArt.description: The history of graffiti in New York City and how pioneering artists who began by painting subway cars are now selling their art for thousands.

breedOfMotion.title: Breed of Motion Documentary
breedOfMotion.description: Documentary about the pioneering dance collective Breed of Motion, formed by Tyrone Proctor and other pioneers in the 1980s. Featured prominent dancers including Archie Burnett and Willi Ninja, the group was instrumental in the evolution of waacking, punking, and contemporary black street dance culture. They performed and choreographed for TV shows and music acts like the Isley Brothers and New Kids on the Block.

campbellockWebsite.title: Don Campbell’s Website
campbellockWebsite.description: Personal website of Don Campbell, the creator of locking (originally called Campbellock). Features his personal story, the history of the dance, and authentic insights into the birth of one of the most iconic funk styles.
campbellockWebsite.author: Don Campbell

theLockersWebsite.title: The Lockers Website
theLockersWebsite.description: Website of The Lockers, the legendary dance crew that changed the face of dance. Features the seven original members, their history, celebrity testimonials, and rare photos from the group that pioneered locking in popular culture.
theLockersWebsite.author: The Lockers Dance Crew

example.title: Example Resource
example.description: This is a placeholder for real resources that need to be verified and added.
example.author: TBD

checkYourBodyAtTheDoor.title: Check Your Body at the Door
checkYourBodyAtTheDoor.description: A documentary about remarkable underground House dancers in NYC during the golden decade of the 1990s. Featuring rare dance club footage, the film follows master free-stylists into the clubs, their jobs, and their everyday lives.
checkYourBodyAtTheDoor.author: Sally Sommer & Charles Atlas
checkYourBodyAtTheDoor.siteName: Check Your Body at the Door
checkYourBodyAtTheDoor.context: Groundbreaking documentary about underground House dancers in NYC during the golden decade of the 1990s

trailer.title: Check Your Body at the Door - Official Trailer
trailer.description: Official trailer for the groundbreaking documentary about underground House dancers in NYC during the 1990s.

comeAsYouAreLoft.title: Come As You Are
comeAsYouAreLoft.description: A short documentary exploring the cultural and social impact of the legendary Loft era in NYC. This film discusses how the ritual of club dancing and radical self expression ignited unity and healing within the Latino and African American communities of New York. Understand how 'The Loft' laid the roots for the birth of the international phenomenon of House culture and music.
comeAsYouAreLoft.author: Various Artists

iWasThereWhenHouseTookOver.title: I Was There When House Took Over The World: House Was Born
iWasThereWhenHouseTookOver.description: How social unrest and Chicago's underground gay clubs led to a global dance movement. This documentary about the history of house music explores the origins of the genre, and features interviews with Nile Rodgers, Traxman, Jesse Saunders, Honey Dijon and Marshall Jefferson.
iWasThereWhenHouseTookOver.author: Various Artists

parisIsBurning.title: Paris is Burning
parisIsBurning.description: Groundbreaking 1990 documentary that chronicles the ball culture of New York City and the African-American, Latino, gay, and transgender communities involved in it. The film explores themes of race, class, gender, and sexuality while documenting the art of voguing and the elaborate social and competitive ball scene.
parisIsBurning.author: Jennie Livingston

kikiDocumentary.title: Kiki
kikiDocumentary.description: Contemporary documentary exploring the current Kiki ballroom scene in New York City. The film follows seven characters from the Kiki community, a movement created by and for LGBTQ+ youth of color, showcasing how the ballroom culture continues to evolve and provide safe spaces for self-expression and community building.
kikiDocumentary.author: Sara Jordenö

voguingHouseBallroomScene.title: Voguing and the House Ballroom Scene of New York City 1989-92
voguingHouseBallroomScene.description: Harlem's gay ball subculture of the late 1980s is superbly documented in this trove of previously unseen photographs. In 1989, Malcolm McLaren had his only number one hit with a single called 'Deep in Vogue.' Early the next year, Madonna had one of the biggest hits of her career, with the single 'Vogue,' and when Jennie Livingston's film Paris Is Burning arrived in cinemas the same year, winning the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival, the mainstream got hip to New York City's extraordinary ball culture, from which the film and McLaren and Madonna's songs had arisen.
voguingHouseBallroomScene.author: Stuart Baker (Editor)

theQueenDoc.title: The Queen
theQueenDoc.description: The groundbreaking 1968 documentary about the Miss All-America Camp Beauty Pageant that introduced audiences to competitive drag culture. The film captures Crystal LaBeija's iconic moment calling out racial bias in the pageant, which sparked her to form the influential House of LaBeija and launch the Black & Brown ballroom scene.

howDoILookDoc.title: How Do I Look
howDoILookDoc.description: Wolfgang Busch's decade-long documentation of ball culture from the mid-1990s to 2000s, featuring legends like Willi Ninja, Jose Xtravaganza, Kevin Ultra-Omni, Octavia St. Laurent, and Pepper LaBeija. The film explores the scene's roots in the 1920s Harlem Renaissance and its influence on mainstream artists and musicians.

strikeAPoseDoc.title: Strike A Pose
strikeAPoseDoc.description: The story of seven young dancers, including Jose and Luis Xtravaganza, who joined Madonna on her controversial 1990 Blond Ambition World Tour. Twenty-five years after Truth or Dare, the film revisits these dancers' lives and their impact on sexual freedom and gay culture worldwide.

myHouseDoc.title: My House
myHouseDoc.description: Elegance Bratton's contemporary look at ballroom culture through this Viceland documentary series. Following modern ballroom personalities like Tati 007, Alex Mugler, Jelani Mizrahi, Lolita Balenciaga, and Relish Milan in today's New York scene across ten episodes.

punkingDanceInstagram.title: @punking.dance
punkingDanceInstagram.description: Official Archive of the artform of Punking from beginning to evolution researched & curated by @alyssachloe_22 @viktormanoel
punkingDanceInstagram.author: Alyssa Chloe & Viktor Manoel

viktorManoelPunkingInterview.title: Interview: Viktor Manoel Is Keeping Punking Alive
viktorManoelPunkingInterview.description: In-depth interview with Viktor Manoel, the last remaining originator of Punking, covering the dance’s creation in 1970s LA gay clubs, his work with David Bowie, the AIDS crisis impact, and his mission to preserve the authentic history and spirit of the dance.
viktorManoelPunkingInterview.author: Hanne Os Wold

viktorManoelDanceMogulPt1.title: Viktor Manoel Dance Mogul Magazine Exclusive 2012 (Punking) Part 1
viktorManoelDanceMogulPt1.description: First part of Viktor Manoel’s exclusive interview with Dance Mogul Magazine in 2012, discussing the history and origins of Punking dance from the perspective of one of its original creators.
viktorManoelDanceMogulPt1.author: Dance Mogul Magazine

viktorManoelDanceMogulPt2.title: Viktor Manoel Dance Mogul Magazine Exclusive 2012 (Punking) Part 2
viktorManoelDanceMogulPt2.description: Second part of Viktor Manoel’s exclusive interview with Dance Mogul Magazine, continuing the exploration of Punking history and its cultural significance in the dance community.
viktorManoelDanceMogulPt2.author: Dance Mogul Magazine

viktorManoelDanceMogulPt3.title: Viktor Manoel Dance Mogul Magazine Exclusive 2012 (Punking) Part 3
viktorManoelDanceMogulPt3.description: Final part of Viktor Manoel’s exclusive interview series, addressing the history of Punking and discussing important issues like bullying within the dance community.
viktorManoelDanceMogulPt3.author: Dance Mogul Magazine

lifeAndDeathNYDanceFloor.title: Life and Death on the New York Dance Floor, 1980–1983
lifeAndDeathNYDanceFloor.description: Chronicles the tumultuous period of New York's dance culture from 1980-1983, charting sonic and social eruptions in the city's subterranean party venues. Explores how post-disco, post-punk, and hip hop scenes became marked by plurality, interaction, and convergence before gentrification and other forces brought this creative era to an end.
lifeAndDeathNYDanceFloor.author: Tim Lawrence

sallySommerHouseDancing.title: C'mon to my house: Underground-House Dancing
sallySommerHouseDancing.description: Academic research article examining the underground house dancing scene and its cultural significance. Published in Dance Research Journal by Cambridge University Press, this scholarly work provides in-depth analysis of house dance culture and community.
sallySommerHouseDancing.author: Sally R. Sommer

czarinaMiraniHouseHistory.title: Spin Slide and Jack: A History of House Dancing
czarinaMiraniHouseHistory.description: Comprehensive exploration of house dancing history covering the fundamental moves and cultural evolution of the dance style. Features interviews with key figures and analysis of the dance's development from Chicago and New York scenes.
czarinaMiraniHouseHistory.author: Czarina Mirani

barryWaltersBurningDownHouse.title: Burning Down the House
barryWaltersBurningDownHouse.description: Early journalistic coverage of house music and dance culture from 1986, providing contemporary perspective on the emerging scene. This SPIN magazine article captures the energy and innovation of house culture during its formative years.
barryWaltersBurningDownHouse.author: Barry Walters

philCheesemanHistoryOfHouse.title: The History Of House
philCheesemanHistoryOfHouse.description: Comprehensive historical overview of house music from its Chicago origins to global expansion. Originally published in DJ Magazine, this detailed chronicle traces the genre's evolution, key figures, and cultural impact from the 1970s through the early 2000s.
philCheesemanHistoryOfHouse.author: Phil Cheeseman

simonReynoldsGenerationEcstasy.title: Generation Ecstasy: Into the World of Techno and Rave Culture
simonReynoldsGenerationEcstasy.description: Comprehensive examination of electronic dance music culture including house music origins. Reynolds provides detailed analysis of how house music developed from disco and influenced the broader electronic music landscape.
simonReynoldsGenerationEcstasy.author: Simon Reynolds

doYouRememberHouse.title: Do You Remember House?: Chicago's Queer of Color Undergrounds
doYouRememberHouse.description: Do You Remember House? tells the full story of the emergence, queer remediation, and memorialization of house in Chicago from its beginnings in the late '70s to the present. Based on expansive research in archives and his extensive conversations with the makers of house in Chicago's parks, clubs, museums, and dance studios, author Micah Salkind argues that queer remediation and adaptation of house music by crossover communities in its first decade shaped the ways that Chicago producers, DJs, dancers, and promoters today invoke and mobilize the genre as an archive of collectivity and congregation.
doYouRememberHouse.author: Micah E. Salkind

discographiesBook.title: Discographies: Dance, Music, Culture and the Politics of Sound
discographiesBook.description: Experiencing disco, hip hop, house, techno, drum 'n' bass and garage, Discographies plots a course through the transatlantic dance scene of the last twenty-five years. It discusses the problems posed by contemporary dance culture of both academic and cultural study and finds these origins in the history of opposition to music as a source of sensory pleasure. Discussing such issues as technology, club space, drugs, the musical body, gender, sexuality and pleasure, Discographies explores the ecstatic experiences at the heart of contemporary dance culture. It suggests why politicians and agencies as diverse as the independent music press and public broadcasting should be so hostile to this cultural phenomenon.
discographiesBook.author: Jeremy Gilbert & Ewan Pearson

ui.noResourcesMessage: Resources for this style are being curated. Check back soon!

landmarks.sectionDescription: Significant venues and locations that shaped this dance style
landmarks.heritageNote: These venues and locations represent the authentic spaces where dance culture flourished. Many have closed, but their legacy lives on through the communities and movements they fostered.

the-warehouse-chicago.name: The Warehouse
the-warehouse-chicago.significance: The legendary Chicago club where DJ Frankie Knuckles pioneered house music from 1977-1982. This venue gave house music its name and became the spiritual home of the genre and its associated dance culture.

paradise-garage-nyc.name: Paradise Garage
paradise-garage-nyc.significance: Iconic NYC club (1977-1987) where DJ Larry Levan created the template for modern club culture. The venue’s sound system and community fostered both house music and voguing culture.

1520-sedgwick-avenue.name: 1520 Sedgwick Avenue
1520-sedgwick-avenue.significance: The Bronx apartment building where DJ Kool Herc threw the party on August 11, 1973, that is widely credited as the birth of hip-hop culture, including breaking and hip-hop dance.

webster-hall-nyc.name: Webster Hall
webster-hall-nyc.significance: Historic Manhattan ballroom (since 1886) that has hosted voguing balls and LGBTQ+ community events, serving as an important venue for ballroom culture development.

bronx-river-houses.name: Bronx River Houses
bronx-river-houses.significance: Public housing complex in the Bronx where Afrika Bambaataa founded the Zulu Nation in the 1970s, becoming a crucial hub for early hip-hop culture and breaking battles.

cedar-park.name: Cedar Park
cedar-park.significance: Bronx park that served as an important outdoor venue for early breaking battles and hip-hop jams throughout the 1970s and 1980s, fostering the development of breaking culture.

ginos-ii.name: Gino’s II
ginos-ii.significance: All-ages nightclub in Hollywood (1976-1985) where punking dance originated. The term ’punking’ was coined here by DJ and dance originator Michael Angelo Harris, who used ’punk’ as empowerment in the underground gay dance community.

tracks-nightclub.name: Tracks
tracks-nightclub.significance: Legendary NYC nightclub that was a central venue for ballroom culture and voguing in the 1980s and 1990s, hosting major balls and fostering the competitive ballroom scene.

paradise-ballroom.name: Paradise Ballroom
paradise-ballroom.significance: One of the first gay discos in Los Angeles (1974-1977) where ’Posing’ dance was performed - dramatic freezes emulating Hollywood stars like Greta Garbo. This blending with other styles became the foundation of punking.

peanuts-club.name: Peanuts
peanuts-club.significance: West Hollywood nightclub (1979-1995) that started as a lesbian club but became mixed, catering to different LGBTQ+ crowds. Featured two bars, pool table, and mid-sized dance floor with floor-to-ceiling mirrors.

keyFigures.title: Key Figures
keyFigures.description: Meet the influential artists and pioneers who shaped this dance style. These individuals created, innovated, and preserved the culture for future generations.
